text: {"answer": "B", "reasoning": "Statement i is incorrect: Under Swiss law, a popular initiative violating jus cogens (peremptory norms of international law) is invalid, but violation of the ECHR alone is not a ground for invalidation. The Federal Assembly does not declare initiatives invalid merely for conflicting with the ECHR; such initiatives can be put to a vote. Statement ii is incorrect: Swiss civil procedure applies a narrow concept of res judicata (limited to the operative part/dispositif of the judgment). Findings of fact and legal assessments in the reasoning do not become binding in subsequent disputes. Statement iii is correct: Under Swiss contract law (Art. 18 CO), when both interpretations are equally admissible, there is dissent and no contract comes into existence - this reflects the principle of normative consent interpretation failing. Statement iv is correct: The 2nd parentel (Parentel) in Swiss succession law includes the parents of the deceased and their descendants (siblings, nieces, nephews, etc.)."}
